@thetkkong Varunsrin.eth

This tricks @opensea and @etherscan into showing them as legitimate "Mint" Events, and unsuspecting users may ape into these fake NFT's.

Expect these attacks to become more common, always be careful when buying new NFT's!

So the contract creator can mint the same token to the same people, again and again, generating thousands of events.

Which they do here:  https://t.co/JvPlkvRTIq

The flipped ape contract exploits this to trick users. It emits a transfer event when a new token is minted, just like the ERC-721 spec says. 

But it doesn't implement the logic to prevent the same token from being minted again.

This standard is called ERC-721, and it defines the functions (the ABI) and a set of rules for how they should work (the logic).

It's very easy to check if a contract complies with the ABI, but hard to check if it complies with the logic.

All NFT contracts implement the same ABI, which makes writing NFT apps easy.

If you write code that checks for transfers from one NFT contract, it will work just fine when pointed at another. That's how @etherscan and @opensea can easily track all NFT's.

So to talk to a compiled smart contract, you need the source code. Or at least enough of it to know the names and shapes of the functions in the bytecode. 

This stripped down version of the source is called an ABI.

Ethereum smart contracts expose functions to read or write on-chain data. 

They're written in human-readable Solidity but are compiled into very efficient byte code before being deployed. 

The downside of byte code is that it's not readable.

A closer look at a flipped punk shows the same one minted hundreds of times by different people. 

Someone is spoofing events, making it look like famous collectors are minting NFT's when they aren't.

How is this happening? https://t.co/dS7jIfF3Ld

If you follow @punk4156  or @CozomoMedici on OpenSea, you may have noticed that they're minting hundreds of flipped punks and apes. 

But don't go minting any yourself just yet.

https://t.co/YHL5p3r8NU

todays airdrops are a good starting point, but there's a lot to improve on. the winning systems will figure out how to:

- favor users over hoarders.
- distribute value gradually and predictably.
- use simple algos instead of governance votes.

web2 network effects == get users
web3 network effects == give to users

paradoxically, the more you give away the more valuable your share becomes (up to a point).

my favorite bit about explaining web3 to web2 people is the moment when it clicks that airdrops are a way to finance cac with future potential instead of cash on hand.

the second part is when they realize how easy retention is when users are literally invested in your success.

@mlevchin why not both?
